entry.title: Re: How does Effort Deviation adjustment persist across p...
entry.content: Absolutely, and thank you so much for your detailed explanation and support. From what I understand now: The compensation for effort deviation is recalculated and applied only to the current Forecast Month, based on the gap between plan and actual up to that horizon. When the Forecast Month moves forward, the system does not cumulatively carry over compensation month by month, but instead recalculates it for the new Forecast Month. However, the values that were calculated in earlier periods (when those months were the active Forecast Month) are kept as historical snapshots, so the compensation that was once applied in a past period is not cancelled or overwritten, but remains as part of that period‚Äôs historical data. In other words, current compensation lives in the current Forecast Month, while past compensations stay in past periods as historical results, which is why I can still see an adjusted deviation in 2024005 even though the current Forecast Month is now 2025004. Please let me know if this understanding is correct or if I‚Äôm still missing an important detail. Thanks again for taking the time to clarify this behavior in such a clear way.

entry.title: Re: IH01 ‚Äì Plant Field Is Prefilled by Default
entry.content:
Many fields are pre-filled using a parameter known as the SPA/GPA parameter. You can access this parameter by pressing F1 on the field to display technical information, where the parameter ID is listed as 'WRK' in your case?

The initial value for these fields is derived from the parameter value in transaction SU3. This value is then read and updated by various transactions using the parameter ID 'WRK,' which means the last used plant is set as the default.

Occasionally, the dynpro does not carry the parameter ID value, but the PBO/PAI modules use GET/SET PARAMETER ID statements to handle it.

Tips:

  • Transaction IH01 allows the creation of a user default variant. You can create one with the name 'U' + user_id, which might enable you to force the value of p_werk.
  • Alternatively, you can utilize existing BAdIs (Business Add-Ins) or implicit enhancement points to clear the parameter ID 'WRK.' For example, you can use BADI_EAM_STRUCTURE_LIST and test for a BAdI that executes early in the transaction.

entry.title: Re: Fixed asset: Asset Class without Useful Life
entry.content:
Create a Custom Depreciation Key for assets that should not undergo depreciation.

  • Depreciation Method: Set it to 'None' with a 0% rate.
  • Transaction Code AW01: Use this to define the new depreciation key.
  • Transaction Code OAWS: Use this to assign the depreciation key to the relevant asset classes

NB: Check if a key named '0000' already exists, as it might be suitable (used for AUC)

Assign this depreciation key to your asset. Note that the useful life will only be utilized in certain reporting scenarios.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
@appel_solar_dk : Thanks for sharing your thoughts. The article can be thought of like a thought experiment, trying to weight the hurdles and benefits of "consequently shifting left". It might be incomplete and not respect all specific cases. And yes, you are right with all points. These are considerable aspects, also from an organizational, staffing and cultural perspective when "shift left" the responsibility and not only the logic. So, the shift left approach suddenly grows in impact, if done consequently. Showing this was one of the intentions. Apply the thought for your points consequently to your scenarios and I would expect that you get a good first checklist if and under which circumstances shift left (which has its benefits for me, no doubt) is reasonable.

About c: Formally, the 3 different roles you mention are reference characteristics of 0CUSTOMER ( for the BW people). If you would have needed additional attributes in the past, you would need a new info object (I call them derived) with more data, independently from where you read the data. But this might be a customer-specific extension. If the case is so specific in the "new world" that it can not be derived from the central customer master data, you would need in the "new world" a custom data product generator, so you would pick up the definition and the responsibility , and that would be against "shift left", unless you are organizationally belonging to the backend. 

Like with most discussions around data modeling, there is no black and white, it's a thought model to handle complexity of a (source) data model. Look at LSA(++). There were plenty of discussions and interpreations back then. I saw total overkills in staging in quite some systems.

But over time, certain common ground was established in many systems. Same happens in the medallion architecture, and same will happen sooner or later here, I guess, especially if SAP succeeds with their idea.

Kind regards, Philipp

entry.title: Re: Using Migration Assessment to Plan Your SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migra
entry.content:
Hi Vinay,

thanks for sharing your perspective and for linking your blog. This is an important discussion, and I appreciate you raising it.

Just to clarify our positioning: we consistently highlight that the Migration Assessment provides an estimation of the technical migration effort only, based on static analysis of PI/PO artifacts. It explicitly does not include effort for testing, business validation, cutover and go-live activities, or sender and receiver system adaptations.

These aspects are highly customer dependent, and so far we have not found a reliable way to derive them automatically via a tool, as they depend on the customer‚Äôs chosen frameworks, governance model, and quality requirements. That said, we are always open to feedback if you see an approach on how such aspects could be meaningfully included.

This is why we always recommend a follow-up deep-dive workshop, typically together with SAP or our partners, to validate assumptions and create a realistic end-to-end migration plan. We have strong SAP teams and partners supporting customers in exactly this phase.

Regarding the example you mentioned (e.g. ~700 days for 1000+ interfaces), I would be very interested to better understand the drivers behind such an estimation. From our experience over the last year, we have seen several projects where customers with large landscapes (100+ interfaces) achieved a significantly lower average effort per interface, provided the migration was well prepared and executed in a structured way.

Of course, this is not something we would generalize blindly ‚Äî preparation, planning, interface patterns, and governance make a big difference. Key factors we typically see influencing migration efficiency are early clustering of interfaces, identifying synergies, starting with simpler interfaces, and at the same time addressing more complex ones in parallel.

It would be great to learn more about the specific constraints or patterns you see driving higher effort in such scenarios. Feedback like this helps us further sharpen how we position the assessment and guide both customers and partners.

Best regards,
Richard

entry.title: Re: Is output print preview button available in Manage Sa...
entry.content:
No, the app does not provide a Print Preview button by default. That's because Fiori apps of type "Manage" do not include output functions directly.

To answer your second question: You can't directly add a Print Preview button as you can not enhance the app itself. The app is SAP-delivered and no key-user extensible at header-action level is provided - to my knowledge.  But what you can do is, you can add a custom tile linking to a custom Print Preview app. In other words, you can build a custom as follows:

  • A side‚Äëby‚Äëside CAP/RAP app
  • That calls Output Management APIs
  • Embedded in the Fiori Launchpad as a tile or navigation link

    I hope that it helped.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM C_STC Certification Reimagined: From Multiple Choice to AI Roleplay
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to announce that the SAP Cloud ALM C_STC certification has moved to SAP‚Äôs reimagined certification experience on learning.sap.com. The assessment is now scenario-based AI roleplay, designed to reflect real stakeholder conversations and decision making. To support this change, we are introducing a refreshed Learning Journey that consists of both updated courses and newly created courses‚Äîso you can prepare with confidence.

 

Announcement

SAP Cloud ALM C_STC (SAP Certified Associate ‚Äì Solution Transformation Consultant with SAP Cloud ALM) is now available on the new SAP Certification platform and aligned with SAP‚Äôs reimagined certification approach.

C_STC is assessed through scenario-based interaction (AI roleplay), intended to mirror real project stakeholder conversations and validate how you apply knowledge in context.

For already-certified professionals: please follow the official guidance on maintaining certification (e.g., take the delta course and stay-certified assessments) as applicable.

 

What Changed (and Why It Matters)

The reimagined model shifts the focus from memorization to outcomes: practical, performance-based assessment, open-book by design, and timeboxed challenges that resemble real project work. The goal is to prove what you can do‚Äîhow you structure a response, use available resources, and turn understanding into an actionable recommendation.

 

Refreshed Learning Journey: Updated + New Courses for STCs

To match the new certification experience, we strengthened the learning path for Solution Transformation Consultants (STCs). The refreshed Learning Journey brings together updated courses and newly created courses into a clearer end-to-end storyline‚Äîfrom the integrated toolchain and SAP Cloud ALM fundamentals, through implementation and operations, and into how SAP Cloud ALM supports RISE with SAP and Clean Core topics.

Key Courses in the Learning Journey: Transforming for Success with SAP Cloud ALM 

BTM004 (NEW) ‚Äì Navigating RISE with SAP Transformations Leveraging the Integrated Toolchain: A short, sprint-based case study that shows how SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio, and SAP Cloud ALM work together as an integrated toolchain to enable data-driven, end-to-end transformation delivery‚Äîand how to reuse the provided assets in customer conversations.

CALM01(Updated) ‚Äì Introducing SAP Cloud ALM: Your starting point for a unified view of SAP Cloud ALM across implementation and operations. It helps you evaluate Cloud ALM‚Äôs value (cost reduction, faster time-to-market, operational efficiency) and includes a dedicated Transition unit to support your move to SAP Cloud ALM.

CALM05 (NEW) ‚Äì Onboarding, Setting Up, and Administering SAP Cloud ALM: A practical onboarding and setup guide that takes you from requesting SAP Cloud ALM to user onboarding and role assignments, and then into key integration and configuration options‚Äîso you can get to meaningful hands-on work faster.

CALM20 (Updated) ‚Äì Implementing with SAP Cloud ALM: A deep dive into using SAP Cloud ALM for agile implementation projects, aligned with SAP Activate. It covers project/team setup, process definition, requirements, testing, analytics, and guidance to plan your transition regarding Implementation features from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM.

CALM61 (NEW) ‚Äì Harnessing SAP Cloud ALM for Effective Transformation Execution with RISE: Learn how SAP Cloud ALM serves as the digital backbone for RISE with SAP, and how it supports Clean Core across five dimensions (processes, data, integration, extensions, operations). It also introduces the purpose and access of the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.

We‚Äôll continue to enhance this Learning Journey with ongoing updates‚Äîstay tuned for what‚Äôs next.

 

How to Prepare for Scenario-Based AI Roleplay

Prepare the way you work: practice explaining your approach, rationale, and trade-offs in clear, structured language. Make sure you can connect SAP Cloud ALM capabilities to the transformation storyline. That combination‚Äîcontent mastery plus communication‚Äîbest matches what a scenario-based assessment is intended to validate.

 

Quick Links

  • Reimagining certification (SAP Learning): https://learning.sap.com/get-certified/reimagining-certification 
  • C_STC certification page: https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-associate-solution-transformation-consultant-with-sap-cloud-alm 
  • Learning Journey: Transforming for Success with SAP Cloud ALM: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/transforming-for-success-with-sap-cloud-alm 
  • SAP Cloud ALM learning portal: https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/learning.html

entry.title: Re: Why do I need to process Service Confirmation?
entry.content:
Dear @ISoma,

In Public Cloud (Service Management), Service Entry Sheet (SES) and Service Confirmation serve two different purposes, even when you are procuring an external service item in a service order

Why SES does not complete the service order:

  • SES = procurement acceptance, it confirms that the supplier delivered the external service against the PO and it is the basis for supplier invoicing and MM/FI postings
  • Service Confirmation = service execution reporting, it confirms that the service activity in the service order was actually executed in the service process and it is what drives the service-order execution status and follow-on steps such as final completion and where relevant billing readiness. SAP describes confirmations as the place to report actuals like duration/material/expenses for service execution

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/adbae5bcd5994f159bf2847a11397b61/f51f9127ec904db69be5bfc40cfcaeb4.html

So, after SES approval, the system still considers the service order item as not yet execution-confirmed from a Service perspective.

What the Confirmation tab is doing and why SAP requires it:

In the standard process, once an activity is completed, a follow-up service confirmation is created and set to Completed and if it is the last one, final Confirmation must be set
That final confirmation is the systems control point to:

  • prove completion of the service work,
  • freeze execution so no further actuals/consumption are expected for that item,
  • drive the service order lifecycle status to Completed because completion is defined as execution is fully confirmed not merely procurement is accepted

More details below:

https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition-service-management/creating-service-orders-and-service-confirmations_d9a942ce-e887-4c86-9c5b-b955255b15ba

Can you set the Service Order to Completed without service confirmation?

In standard Public Cloud NO, not if the item categories/order type are designed to be confirmation-relevant. The Completed lifecycle status is effectively system-controlled based on execution completion logic completion/final confirmation, not just a manual status toggle. If your business requirement is close the order after SES, SAP expects you to still create at least one final service confirmation even if it contains no time/expenses because that is the step that declares execution is finished

Practical options to minimize or avoid manual effort:

Option A: Recommended standard approach

After SES is approved:

  1. Go to Confirmations tab
  2. Create/select the confirmation for the relevant items
  3. Set Status = Completed
  4. Tick Final Confirmation
  5. Save

This is usually a lightweight step, but it is what allows the order to reach Completed

Option B: Automate confirmation creation/completion

If the issue is operational overhead, the typical approach is to automate the creation + completion of the service confirmation triggered by SES approval for example using SAP Build Process Automation or an integration flow. Conceptually this keeps SAP control logic intact but removes manual work

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Universal Revenue Recognition (URR) Configuration Walkthrough ‚Äì Release 2602
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide walks you through the configuration of Universal Revenue Recognition (URR). URR combines Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) and Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR) and therefore consists of two main parts: configuration in EBRR and configuration in CBRR. Because URR leverages the strengths of both approaches, the EBRR and CBRR settings apply to different areas.

 

Configuration in EBRR relates to:

  ‚Äì Integration with business processes

  ‚Äì Account determination

  ‚Äì Posting rules

Configuration in CBRR relates to:

  ‚Äì Deriving attributes for CBRR-related  objects

  ‚Äì Defining standalone selling price (SSP) for price allocation when an SSP cannot be defined in the order system

General steps

Below are the configuration steps at a glance:

Pricing configuration in Sales

  1. Define a condition type for SSP
  2.  Add the SSP condition type to the pricing procedure
  3.  Maintain SSP condition records for the product

Configuration in EBRR:

  1.  Maintain Source Mapping (optional)
  2.  Maintain Accounts for Posting (optional)
  3.  Define Billable Determination Method (required)
  4.  Enable 'Use Revenue Contracts' via the Bundling Scenario

Configuration in CBRR (Revenue and Cost Accounting)

  1.   Maintain contract and POB attributes
  2.   Define Standalone Selling Price (optional ‚Äî only if SSP is not defined in Sales)

This guide focuses on the configuration in EBRR and CBRR. Pricing configuration in Sales for SSP is covered in a separate blog, as it depends on the specific business process.

Prerequisites

  • Activate the relevant scope items for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) and Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR).
  • For EBRR, there are separate scope items for each integration scenario, such as 1K2 (Event Based Revenue Recognition - Sell from Stock) or 3M4 Event-Based Revenue Recognition ‚Äì Service Documents ‚Äì IFRS (3M4)

Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) Setup

Start in the Profitability Analysis area under Revenue Recognition. This is the starting point because EBRR defines the integration scenarios.

Maintain Source for the condition (Optional)

If revenue contracts are used, each pricing condition type must be mapped to a source. The system checks this mapping during revenue contract creation. This step is optional if you do not change SAP‚Äôs default configuration, which already contains predefined mappings.

As you can see, SAP has predefined the mapping of the condition types to the sources.  If you introduce a new condition type or add a condition type to a pricing procedure, ensure you map it to a source in the EBRR configuration.

Example: if you add condition type DSV1 to the pricing scheme in Subscription Billing and DSV1 is not mapped, add DSV1 to source RPC and create custom rules (e.g., rule numbers starting from 1000).

This ensures the condition type is recognized during processing; otherwise, revenue contract creation will fail due to missing source mapping.

Maintain Accounts for the Posting (Optional)

Now we are in the second step, and this step is optional but usually every customer defines its own account.

 

The account determination during posting is defined in event-based revenue recognition. In most cases, you need to define the following accounts

  • Deferrals Account: you define the deferrals account of usage 100
  • Accrued/Contract Asset Account: you define the accruals account of usage 100
  • Revenue Account: Cost Element Accounts of usage 100
  • Unbilled Account: you define the accruals account of usage 103 and the cost element account shall be the same as the one in usage 100.

Maintain Billable Determination Method (required)

Per IFRS 15/ASC 606, you must define what is billable to distinguish billable amounts from contract assets. When 'Use Revenue Contracts' is set, the system validates that the revenue recognition key has a billable determination method.  In ‚ÄòMaintain settings‚Äô for the Revenue Recognition Key, you define how billable is calculated.

Supported method:

  • Billable equals Invoice:
  • Billable follows Percentage of Completion: 
  • Billable at completion:

At least one billable determination method must be maintained for the key used in processing. Otherwise,  you may get an error at configuration to enable ‚ÄòUse Revenue Recontracts‚Äô or later at period end run.

Use the new ‚ÄòBundling Scenario‚Äô Field to Enable ‚ÄòUse Revenue Contracts‚Äô

In this step, we define when a product of a process shall create revenue contract and how different products from different process shall be combined into single revenue contracts.

  • Open ‚ÄòDefine Revenue Recognition Key‚Äô for the relevant Process (e.g., Provider Contract for Subscription Billing).
  • Bundling Scenario is determined by whether an object is created standalone or from a Solution Order.
    • Per Standard Objects: When the object is created directly (without Solution Order).
    • Per Solution Order: When the object is created from a Solution Order

  • When Bundling Scenario is set to Per Solution Order, ‚ÄòUse Revenue Contract‚Äô becomes active for the key.
  • With this, all objects created from a same Solution Order are combined into one revenue contract.
  • This behavior can be applied across different business processes (service contract, provider contract, project, sales order). For example, in one solution order there are service contracts and sales orders, and the revenue recognition key of the service contracts and sales orders are defined as ‚ÄòUse Revenue Contract‚Äô, the  one revenue contract will be created with POBs from each service contract and sales orders.

Advanced ‚Äî Using revenue contracts for standalone objects

  • Using revenue contracts for standalone objects (when bundle scenario is per standalone Objects not created from Solution Order) is supported only via expert configuration.
  • Please raise a request to SAP; SAP reviews the business process and enables the setup if appropriate.

 

Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR) Setup

Maintain Contract Attributes using Business Rule Framework (BRF+) rules

Now we start the configuraiton in CBRR.

  • To enable revenue contract creation, maintain the BRF+ rules required by revenue contracts.
  • You  "Maintain Contract Attributes Business Rules"

Note: The system requires you at least trigger the configuration so that the businss rule is created and put into a transport request. 
You must also allow the pop-up option of your browser!!!

Since 2602, a well-defined pre-delivered configuration is available as part of the application, usually you would not need to change the pre-delivered rules from SAP.  The product ID is taken as the POB Name, and the fulill type and event type are preconfigured according to the reveneu recognition key.

 

Define Standalone Selling Price(Optional)

If the product cannot have a standalone selling price defined in the pricing procedure in solution order), you can still define the SSP using the rule ‚Äòin CBRR. 

You can define the SSP per product and define how the SSP is calculated such as the amount is quarterly based, monthly

 

 

Up to now, the configuration is completed, and you can now run the End-2-End scenario starting from Solution Order to Financial Accounting.

entry.title: Security change with ByD release 2602
entry.content:
As par of security best practices, we are disabling the previewing the attachments in browser or new tab, across ByD.

Same for documents which are opened via the document name and output History

This is significant change of behavior with respective to viewing attachments, customer must download to their local desktop to view the attachment.

 

In 2602 release affects the following areas:

  • Customer Invoicing
  • Sales Orders
  • Supplier Invoices (invoices and credit memos)
  • Payables, Liquidity Management (including Bank Statements)
  • File Management

 

In subsequent releases we disable previewing attachments in remaining places.

 

Benefits:

  • Improved Security : Download only access ensures that sensitive documents are not rendered inside the browser, reducing exposure to browser based vulnerabilities and aligning better with corporate security policies.
  • Reduced Rendering Issues: Some attachments may not display correctly in the browser due to format limitations or browser compatibility issues. Downloading ensures documents are opened in their native application, preserving full quality and formatting.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Hi Phil I hope Madrid is not very cold.

You did a fantastic breakdown of the "Shift Left" into SAP, I liked it; you‚Äôve really captured a model where data is born as a product.

From my perspective, focusing on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and its integration with Databricks or similar, makes us rethink the Medallion Architecture. Still, it is more important to note the role shift required.

The traditional "Bronze" layer (raw dump) becomes less relevant. With SAP BDC, we need a Silver layer effectively moving into the backend or the BDC FOS. The data exposed via CDS views or as Martin says the Data Product Generator, is already semantically rich and governed, if all this works, it removes the need for that initial "landing zone" cleanup we used to do in BW or early Data Lakes.

What you mentioned, "Analytical Extensions" (like Churn Risk or CLV) as sidecar products might be done with  SAP + Databricks and the core "Silver" data product (e.g., Global Material) remains owned by the SAP backend (the "Semantic remains in SAP"), the "Gold" layer sits in Databricks for high-end ML/AI workloads.

The biggest hurdle is the skill gap.  As you noted, backend developers (often ABAP-focused) are now expected to be "Data Product Owners," and that is not in their hands; it's a complete customer restructure.

Data Products is treating the data as a product, meaning there is an owner who is going to continuously curate it. SAP tools are still incomplete for this end-to-end task. BDC is still in the making, so are many customers in this paradigm right now.

Still,  many legacy landscapes ("Brownfield"), and we are yet to see the Data Product Builder and how BDC integrates with non SAP data as BW could do.

I will wait for your next blog.

entry.title: Clean core journey - Guidance, implementation & governance
entry.content:
This blog post aims to give a high-level overview of your clean core journey as part of our S/4HANA Cloud private edition greenfield implementation! It focuses on clean core tracking and governance!

Step 1 

Our clean core journey started with creating an extensibility strategy. This includes raising awareness for the topic and why it is important, as well as creating a common understanding

Step 2

Create your development guidelines based on the extensibility strategy.

Step 3

Review and approve technical specifications.

Step 4

For governance reasons, we created a clean core ATC check variant. We use this check variant in multiple ways:

  1. when releasing TRs
  2. custom code migration app
  3. integrated into our Cloud ALM change & deployment process

We created a second ATC check variant for the exports to Cloud ALM (system view and customer objects).

Step 5

A simple and early way of tracking was using tagging in Cloud ALM - create a tag group and tag your requirements/user stories, specs (documents), and features accordingly! Once available, we started exploring the RISE with SAP Methodology space and its apps in Cloud ALM!

Using its KPIs, the system view app provides a nice overview of the clean core status quo regarding extensibility.

To be honest, I was surprised by the number of Level D objects (especially when seen in relation to the number of Level B objects). So I was looking forward to being able to see which objects are shown as Level D.

Since last Wednesday's delivery, you can dive one lever deeper, by having a look on object level. So, of course, I had to try out the new customer objects app immediately. 

The result list contains the following object types:

  • Enhancement Implementation (#72)
  • Function Group (#3)
  • Program (#19)
  • Class (ABAP Objects) (#3)

All Function groups and a couple of enhancement implementations are from third-party addons.

To cross-check my understanding of the "new" level concept, I had a look at the classification in two different SAP whitepapers:

Source: Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud



Source: Extend SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on premise with ABAP based extensions

In my opinion, the second overview with the examples is quite helpful, as it, for example, also shows that BAdIs that are flagged as SAP internal are also considered as level D. On the other hand, it classifies "custom applications with legacy UI technology (e.g. ABAP report with ALV)" as level B, so I need to check why some of the programs that fall in this category are shown as Level D in the customer objects app.


Side remark: Personally, I am not a big fan of the new level concept. I understand that the old tier concept was difficult for customers who migrated from their ECC systems to S/4HANA. However, if you do a greenfield implementation based on best practices with a Fiori first approach, the old tier concept was the better fit (imho). In such a scenario,  you still don't want to use the old GUI ALV but would instead aim for e.g. a Fiori Elements application - just to give one example!

Coming back to the new customer objects app...in the upcoming weeks, I want to have a closer look at all objects and get a better understanding of the information that is shown on the detail page! Next to the upcoming executive dashboard, another great step forward would be to integrate the new customer objects app with the library app. Being able to import the data from the customer objects app into the library app and navigating to the corresponding library entry would be awesome. Once the library elements are finally linked to requirements, features, and user stories (currently on the roadmap for Q3/2026) that would be next level!

What are your thoughts on the new level concept? Where are you in your clean core journey? How do you track your clean core journey? Happy to get your feedback in the comments!

PS: For those who are new to the topic, I can recommend the learning journey Introducing the Clean Core Approach.

entry.title: Re: MCP Server for On Premise data
entry.content:
Hi Sumant, 

That plan to wrap OData services via an MCP server on BTP is good, but converting everything to ODP/OData means you need to first expose the ECC data as OData services, maintain those services, and then wrap them again via MCP. That's two abstraction layers when you could potentially have one.

We are limited to what OData exposes from ECC or S/4HANA. What about function modules, BAPIs, or custom ABAP logic that isn't (and shouldn't be) exposed as OData?

If we had a pure ABAP MCP server, many things would be solved. Access to tables, FMs, BAPIs, and CDS views that are not odata translated. No Python runtime on BTP, no dependency on FastMCP, just ABAP running where the data already lives.

I know there are already some people on that, and the challenge apparently is implementing the SSE (Server-Sent Events) transport that MCP uses for streaming, which requires an ABAP workaround.

That would be cool also.

entry.title: üéØ Lite Plan Deprecation: Time to Upgrade to Free! üöÄ | SAP Job Scheduling service
entry.content:
üéØ Lite Plan Deprecation: Time to Upgrade to Free! üöÄ

Great news! The SAP Job Scheduling Service is evolving to provide you with better capabilities and a more consistent experience across Trial and Production environments. As part of this evolution, we're saying goodbye to the Lite plan and inviting everyone to upgrade to the superior Free plan! üéâ

 

üìÖ Important Timeline

Here's what you need to know:

DateEventStatus

22 January 2026Lite plan officially deprecated on SAP BTP Trial‚ö†Ô∏è Announced
19 February 2026Last day to create new Lite plan instancesüîí No new instances
Going forwardExisting Lite instances will be removed‚ôªÔ∏è Migrate to Free

‚ÑπÔ∏è Note: SAP BTP Trial accounts typically live for 90 days. Your existing Lite instances will be removed as part of the natural trial lifecycle.

If you want to stay up-to-date with the latest announcements, check out the SAP Job Scheduling Service What's New page.

üåü Why This Change is Good News

The Lite plan served us well, but it was time for an upgrade! Here's why the Free plan is a much better choice:

Lite Plan Limitations üòï

  • üîê Basic authentication only (outdated security model)
  • üîÑ Works differently than production Standard plan (confusing!)
  • üìö Limited REST API capabilities
  • üè¢ No multitenancy support
  • üéì Steeper learning curve when moving to production

Free Plan Advantages üéä

  • üîí OAuth 2.0 authentication - Modern, secure, production-ready
  • üéØ Works like Standard plan - Smooth transition to production
  • üöÄ Full REST API support - All features unlocked
  • üè¢ Multitenancy ready - Build tenant-aware solutions
  • ‚ú® Better integration - Works seamlessly with other BTP services
  • üìä More capabilities - Alert Notification Service, Cloud Foundry tasks, and more!

üìä Plan Comparison: Lite vs. Free vs. Standard

Here's a detailed comparison to help you understand the differences:

FeatureLite (Deprecated)Free ‚≠êStandard

AvailabilityTrial only üß™Trial only üß™ (for now)Trial & Production üåç
AuthenticationBasic Auth üîìOAuth 2.0 üîíOAuth 2.0 üîí
Security ModelUsername/PasswordJWT tokensJWT tokens
Number of SchedulesLimited 15 ‚ö†Ô∏èLimited 15 ‚ö†Ô∏èUnlimited ‚ôæÔ∏è
Minimal Interval1 hour ‚è∞1 hour ‚è∞5 minutes ‚ö°
Multitenancy‚ùå‚úÖ‚úÖ
Alert Notification Service‚ùå‚úÖ‚úÖ
Cloud ALM Monitoring‚ùå‚úÖ‚úÖ
Alignment with StandardDifferent behavior‚úÖ-
SupportCommunity üë•Community üë•SLA-backed üõ°Ô∏è
Production ReadyLearningLearning/Prototyping‚úÖ Yes

üí° Key Takeaway: Free plan gives you almost the same capabilities as Standard plan, just with thoughtful limitations perfect for learning and prototyping. When you're ready for production, the transition is seamless!

üéÅ What You Get with the Free Plan

Let's celebrate what the Free plan brings to the table:

‚è∞ Hourly Scheduling

Schedule jobs every hour - perfect for periodic reports, cleanup tasks, and regular data processing.

üìä 15 Schedules

More than enough for learning, testing, and small applications. Build real-world solutions without hitting limits!

üîî Unlimited Alert Notifications

Integrate with SAP Alert Notification Service to get notified when jobs succeed or fail.

üîí Production-Like Security

Learn OAuth 2.0 authentication in Trial, so you're ready for production. No re-learning required!

üè¢ Multitenancy Support

Build and test tenant-aware applications right in your Trial account.

üöÄ Full Feature Set

Access to Cloud Foundry tasks, async jobs, REST API - everything you need to build sophisticated scheduling solutions!

üéØ Who Should Use the Free Plan?

The Free plan is perfect for:

  • üéì Students & Learners - Explore Job Scheduling without costs
  • üß™ Developers - Prototype and test scheduling logic
  • üé® Proof of Concepts - Build demos and validate ideas
  • üìö Tutorial Followers - Work through our blog posts and documentation
  • üöÄ Indie Developers - Power personal projects and experiments
  • üè¢ Enterprises - Evaluate features before production deployment

üöÄ Getting Started with Free Plan

Ready to make the switch? It's easy!

1Ô∏è‚É£ Create a Free Plan Instance

Using the SAP BTP Cockpit:

  1. Navigate to your Trial subaccount
  2. Go to Service Marketplace
  3. Find SAP Job Scheduling Service
  4. Click Create
  5. Select service plan: free
  6. Follow the wizard to complete creation

Using the Cloud Foundry CLI:

cf create-service jobscheduler free my-scheduler-free

2Ô∏è‚É£ Bind to Your Application

In your manifest.yml:

applications:
  - name: my-app
    services:
      - my-scheduler-free

Or create a service key for REST API access:

cf create-service-key my-scheduler-free my-key
cf service-key my-scheduler-free my-key

3Ô∏è‚É£ Start Scheduling!

Access the dashboard or use the REST API to create your first scheduled job!

üéä Embrace the Upgrade!

This change is all about giving you a better experience. The Free plan:

  • ‚úÖ Teaches you production patterns - No surprises when you go live
  • ‚úÖ Unlocks more features - Do more with your Trial account
  • ‚úÖ Simplifies your journey - One security model to learn
  • ‚úÖ Future-proofs your code - OAuth 2.0 is the standard

We're excited for you to experience the improved capabilities of the Free plan! üöÄ

üìù Appendix: Migration Guide (Optional)

If you currently have applications using the Lite plan and want to migrate to the Free plan, here's what you need to know:

Key Differences to Handle

üîê Authentication Change: Basic Auth ‚Üí OAuth 2.0

Lite Plan (Basic Auth):

// Simple HTTP basic authentication
const credentials = Buffer.from(`${username}:${password}`).toString('base64');
const response = await fetch(jobUrl, {
  headers: {
    'Authorization': `Basic ${credentials}`
  }
});

Free Plan (OAuth 2.0):

// OAuth 2.0 with JWT tokens
const xsenv = require('@sap/xsenv');
const passport = require('passport');
const { JWTStrategy } = require('@sap/xssec');

// Configure authentication
passport.use(new JWTStrategy(xsenv.getServices({ uaa: { tag: 'xsuaa' } }).uaa));

app.use(passport.initialize());
app.use(passport.authenticate('JWT', { session: false }));

üì¶ Service Binding Changes

Lite Plan:

  • No XSUAA service binding required
  • Simple username/password from service key

Free Plan:

  • Requires XSUAA service instance and binding
  • Uses JWT tokens for authentication
  • Service-to-service communication with OAuth 2.0

üîß Migration Steps

  1. Create Free plan instance

    cf create-service jobscheduler free my-scheduler-free

  2. Create or update XSUAA service instance

    Create xs-security.json:

    {
  "xsappname": "my-app",
  "scopes": [
    {
      "name": "$XSAPPNAME.Jobs",
      "description": "SAP Job Scheduling service Scope",
      "grant-as-authority-to-apps": [
        "$XSSERVICENAME(my-scheduler-free)"
      ]
    }
  ]
}

    üìñ Learn more: Secure Access to Job Scheduling Service

    Create XSUAA instance:

    cf create-service xsuaa application my-xsuaa -c xs-security.json

  3. Update your application

    Add dependencies to package.json:

    {
  "dependencies": {
    "@sap/xsenv": "^5.3.0",
    "@sap/xssec": "^4.2.5",
    "passport": "^0.7.0",
    "express": "^4.21.2"
  }
}

  4. Update manifest.yml

    applications:
  - name: my-app
    services:
      - my-scheduler-free
      - my-xsuaa

  5. Redeploy your application

    cf push

üí° Need Help?

You can just drop a comment to start a discussion or look through the following resources:

  • üìñ Job Scheduling Service Documentation
  • üåê SAP Community
  • üìö All Job Scheduler Blog Posts

Happy Scheduling with your new Free plan! üéâüöÄ

The SAP Job Scheduling Service Team

entry.title: Re: OEE performance calculation is being distorted due to...
entry.content:
Hi,

Net Production Time of individual parent resource is calculated using the formula Total Production Time - Shift Break - Unscheduled Downtime - Scheduled Downtime, see Work Center Performance Calculation for more details.

For completed orders generating speed loss, I suggest you raise a ticket for proper investigation and support.

Hope it helps! Br, Manoel

entry.title: Re: How to Disable Message Panel in Create Purchase Order (Advanced)
entry.content:
Dear @Keratiya_D,

What you are seeing is the in-app help / information side panel of Create Purchase Order  Advanced (ME21N/WebGUI). Closing the panel alone does not persist the setting, it is only persisted when the user saves Personal Settings in that app.

How to stop it showing by default (per user):

  • Open Create Purchase Order Advanced
  • Close the left information/help panel
  • Open Personal Settings in the same app
  • Click Save (you do not need to change anything)
  • Close and reopen the app the panel should no longer open automatically for you

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2971411

Best Regards,

Dawid
